unnormalised: **Automotive: Fuel Efficiency Gains Traction in India**
normalised: Automotive: Fuel Efficiency Gains Traction in India

unnormalised: New Delhi, Oct 26th - Indian automakers are increasingly focusing on fuel efficiency, driven by rising petrol prices and stricter emission norms. Dr. Meena Iyer, a leading researcher at IIT Madras, notes that advancements in engine technology, including improved combustion and lighter materials, are key.
normalised: New Delhi, october twenty sixth - Indian automakers are increasingly focusing on fuel efficiency, driven by rising petrol prices and stricter emission norms. Doctor Meena Iyer, a leading researcher at I I T Madras, notes that advancements in engine technology, including improved combustion and lighter materials, are key.

unnormalised: The average fuel efficiency of cars sold in India has risen by approximately 15% in the last 5 years. This translates to significant savings for consumers, with some models offering mileage figures exceeding 25 km per liter.
normalised: The average fuel efficiency of cars sold in India has risen by approximately fifteen percent in the last five years. This translates to significant savings for consumers, with some models offering mileage figures exceeding twenty five kilometer per liter.

unnormalised: Government initiatives like the Bharat Stage VI (BS6) emission standards are further pushing manufacturers to innovate. Tata Motors and Mahindra are actively investing in electric vehicle (EV) technology to enhance fuel efficiency and reduce reliance on fossil fuels.
normalised: Government initiatives like the Bharat Stage six (B S six) emission standards are further pushing manufacturers to innovate. Tata Motors and Mahindra are actively investing in electric vehicle (E V) technology to enhance fuel efficiency and reduce reliance on fossil fuels.

unnormalised: Experts at ARAI (Automotive Research Association of India) predict that future advancements in hybrid technology and alternative fuels like CNG will further boost fuel efficiency, reducing both running costs and the environmental footprint of vehicles in the bustling cities like Mumbai and Chennai. A recent study showed a 10% increase in fuel efficiency translates to savings of Rs. 5,000 annually for the average car owner, besides reducing carbon footprint per sq ft.
normalised: Experts at A R A I (Automotive Research Association of India) predict that future advancements in hybrid technology and alternative fuels like C N G will further boost fuel efficiency, reducing both running costs and the environmental footprint of vehicles in the bustling cities like Mumbai and Chennai. A recent study showed a ten percent increase in fuel efficiency translates to savings of rupee five thousand annually for the average car owner, besides reducing carbon footprint per square foot.
